Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the next number on my call list. It was Sam, my oldest friend, texting in all caps: “HELP! IKEA NIGHTMARE. CAN YOU VIDEO CALL?” I glanced at the clock—prime calling hour. My manager’s words echoed in my head: “Keep up the momentum, you’re on track to break your record!” I could almost taste the bonus, the recognition, the relief of finally not worrying about rent. But Sam’s message tugged at me. We’d always been there for each other, especially in moments like this, when frustration threatened to boil over. I imagined her surrounded by planks and screws, fighting back tears or laughter, hoping I’d pick up. My headset felt heavier. If I paused now, I might lose my rhythm, maybe even fall short of the week’s target. But if I ignored Sam, would I be letting her down when she needed me most? My thumb hovered over the call button, heart pounding, torn between the friend I wanted to be and the employee I was expected to become.
